text:
- Hi, I'm Joe Smyth, senior
vice president of R&D

for Digital and Artificial
Intelligence at Genesys.

So Genesys announced our
partnership with Amazon on Bedrock
for foundational and generative AI
around about this time last year.

Since then, we've been
building out our feature set
on top of that.
What we like about Bedrock

is it brings in the
largest foundational models

like Anthropic, AI21,
Cohere, and the Titan models,

so that we can pick and
choose for the right use cases
to use the correct model.

We also look at open-source
models that we bring on,

and we have two kind of
different types of workloads.
One is high volume and low latency

because we want to apply
AI to every single one

of our 1.5 billion calls to
the platform every month.

To do that, we need to
be able to inference
on every turn of the conversation
between the customer and a bot
or the customer and an agent.

So for that, we take
in open-source models,

we fine tune them on very
specific vertical data
that we have anonymized,

and then we synthesized
into useful conversations
for fine-tuning.
That helps us with latency.

And then for our more
comprehensive use cases,

such as flow mining, which is
looking at the conversations
of your best agents with your customers,

and mining those flows
for intents and entities
and the overall shape of the conversation.
You know, we could take a couple
of thousands of conversations
and have a large language model
like Claude, Anthropic Claude,
work with that to determine intents
and entities over 15, 20 minutes.

All that enables us to keep
the data within the VPC

so that we protect our customer's
data from data sovereignty
and a data locality perspective,

and ensure that all our
compliances continue to be met,
whether it's HITRUST, GDPR,
and all the other 30 compliance
and attestations we have on platform.

So we've been on this journey
on AI with Genesys Cloud
for at least six years now.
We've grown the platform

with conversational AI,
predictive engagement.

Predictive engagement helps
you target your digital
and mobile customers

and to contain them or to
direct them to the correct bot.

Or if they actually call
in or initiate a chat
or web messaging session,
we can determine the best available agent

for their particular intent
at this particular time.
Then we hit conversational AI,
whether it's voicebots or chatbots,
and as they move towards virtual agents,
as we bring in large language models

to really move the
needle on the complexity
of conversations we can automate,
we're continuing to build that out
with our own natural language processing,

but also the Bedrock models
as I described earlier,
to move the needle on the user experience
and move the needle on the complexity
of conversations we can automate.

Then the other part of
is assisting the agent

when a conversation actually
lands on their desktop.

Among a number of elements
to that one is context.

So who is this person
and what is their intent
so that agent can move very quickly

to solving their problem
rather than data gathering.
And that builds empathy.
You know, empathy is not,
"Oh, I'm sorry, you had a problem."

Empathy is, "I am going
to solve your problem."
We're now building copilots using LLMs
to understand at a much broader level

what the intent is doing
entity extraction on the fly,
been able to do tasks in the background
on behalf of the agent.

And all of that is built on
either open-source models
that we're fine-tuning and training
on GPUs within Amazon and Genesys Cloud
or the Bedrock foundational models.

So we're now at over 15
regions across the globe,
plus FedRAMP.
That has really helped us scale.
We keep adding regions:
a second region in Japan,
a second region in the US.
That global footprint and the tooling

and scalability that AWS
brings in all those regions
helps us seamlessly grow.
So Genesys Cloud is completely API-driven
and event-driven from the ground up,
and that's enabled by Amazon Web Services
and all the services within that.
That allow us to scale,

but also to very quickly
build the data flows
that our customers need.

So we're moving towards
an event-data platform

that allow our customers
to energize that data

within the platform for
usage in journey analytics
and journey management.
And it's the tooling within AWS
that has helped us to scale that out.
